Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Otago Two weeks is really too short of a time... If the jump up is temporarily caused by some version of prostatitis... even asymptomatic prostatitis, then two weeks is not enough time to allow it to calm down. A jump from under 2, to over 8, is much more likely caused by such a inflammatory situation than by cancer. However, given your father's experience, I doubt you or your doctor are willing to wait 3 months. So go ahead and get the test... two weeks is NOT waiting too long by any means. Good that at age 40 you got a benchmark measurement of your normal psa, which assuming this latest one is due to a "itis" of some sort, will leave you with a mark from which to judge future psa results. Let us know the results. I would love to find out that this is all caused by some inflammatory situation. I've been reading articles all over the place looking for another cause which fits my symptoms, or lack thereof. I think the two week retest was more to validate the accuracy of the first test rather than see if something had changed in me in two weeks. In the meantime, I went in for the urinalysis earlier today and the results came back amazingly quickly. Everything looks to be within normal ranges. WBC was 0/HPF which seems to rule out asympomatic prostatitis (though that's based on my poor use of Google rather than a discussion with the urologist since their office is closed). Also, unrelated, I realized as I was looking up test results that I was wrong about my initial PSA a year ago... it was 1.8 not 1.35. Not sure how I messed that up. I am currently swinging wildly between "it must be something else, just need to figure out what" and "it must be cancer". Waiting and not knowing is terrible. Thanks all for listening - it helps to have a place to vent/share. Jason
Posts.Title: High PSA at 40 years old - could use some advice

Posts.Title: High PSA at 40 years old - could use some advice

Posts.Content: Thank you all very much for both the support and advice. I was, indeed, referred to a urologist after last year's slightly elevated result. I just spoke with his nurse and she's going to check with him about doing the FTPSA. She also suggested a urinalysis just to rule out an aysmptomatic infection. The lab that did the test is the in-house lab for our hospital so I'm assuming they have their act together. Thank you all so much. When I got the voicemail from the doctor's office that I needed to call to discuss my results and treatment plan, my stomach dropped. It's really helpful to have a group of supportive people to share with and to hear from voices with experience. Thanks, Jason
Posts.Title: High PSA at 40 years old - could use some advice

Posts.Content: I'm 40 years old and had my first PSA test a year ago after my father died of aggressive prostate cancer at the age of 66. My result then was 1.35 and though this was a bit high, my doctor told me not to worry about it and have it retested in a year. Now, a year later, I just received a call from my urologist's nurse telling me that the test this year was 8.1. She asked about the possibility of a UTI but I don't seem to have any of the symptoms of that. She said they thought it could be a lab error and they want me to go in to have it retested in two weeks. I am, quite frankly, freaking out. After watching my dad go through it - and with two kids in my house under four years old, I'm trying hard not to be fatalistic. I have a couple questions if anyone has advice. First, how important is time right now? Is waiting two weeks for a retest a big deal? Objectively it doesn't seem like that long but emotionally it seems like an eternity during which things could go from bad to even worse. How worried should I be? This seems like a really high velocity assuming the test was accurate. Would this mean that the cancer is very aggressive or that it's already spread? Anything else I should be thinking about or doing right now? Thanks everyone for any advice. Jason
Posts.Title: High PSA at 40 years old - could use some advice

Posts.Content: I forgot to mention that the doctor also did a DRE last year which was apparently normal.
Posts.Title: High PSA at 40 years old - could use some advice

Posts.Content: I forgot to mention that the doctor also did a DRE last year which was apparently normal.

Posts.Title: High PSA at 40 years old - could use some advice

Posts.Content: Sorry, I should have mentioned that I'm 41 years old. Also, I did a round of Cipro after the September 2016 test. I don't seem to have any major symptoms of BPH. I've had occasional (rare at once every few months) rectal pain upon ejaculation or defecation though it's infrequent. Based on that I asked about the PCA3 test but my urologist recommended against it - said it was very uncomfortable and he didn't think it was worth it. The concern about my family history is the thing that scared me the most when the first high PSA result came in.
Posts.Title: Thoughts on high and bouncing PSA

Posts.Content: August of last year I posted in this thread about high PSA. The last year has been interesting and I could use some advice. The short history: Father died a couple years ago of aggressive prostate cancer at the age of 66. Doctor recommended annual PSA. 06/12/2015 PSA 1.80 DRE normal, prostate "small" 08/15/2016 PSA 8.02 08/29/2016 PSA 7.32 09/13/2016 PSA 4.79 10/13/2016 PSA 3.81 Ordered free/total PSA but lab only does the free test if above 4. 01/09/2017 PSA 2.55 DRE normal, prostate "small" 04/10/2017 PSA 3.26 The doctor has recommended late last year that we monitor every three months. The high number and subsequent drop seems to point to something other than cancer as the cause which made me very happy. The latest result came in higher than the previous three month test and the doctor has ordered another test in six weeks. He says he recommends a biopsy if the next result doesn't go back down. I realize this last test isn't actually that much higher than the previous one but the direction was distressing and honestly I'm more concerned now that the doctor is talking about biopsy again. Presumably he wouldn't be thinking about that unless he thought there was a good reason. So, I have a couple questions. First, if it were you would you go get a second opinion at this point or just keep going and possibly get the biopsy? Second, does a biopsy seem reasonable at this point? I'd like to know the free/total number because that seems like it might be informative but apparently the lab will only do the breakdown for results over 4. Thanks for any words of wisdom that you can provide! Jason
Posts.Title: Thoughts on high and bouncing PSA

Posts.Content: Sorry, I should have mentioned that I'm 41 years old. Also, I did a round of Cipro after the September 2016 test. I don't seem to have any major symptoms of BPH.
